Environmental and social assessment report

Iraq - Emergency Road Rehabilitation
            Project : environmental assessment

subtopic: Environmental Management,Transport Security,Roads & Highways,Road Safety,Transport and Environment
admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Road Rehabilitation
            Project will be processed as an Emergency Recovery
            Operation. Considering the emergency situation and the
            current security conditions in Iraq, the Environmental and
            Social Screening Assessment Framework (ESSAF) designed for
            Iraq will be used for this project. This project entails
            road rehabilitation, improvement of village access roads,
            rehabilitation and upgrading of the Erbil to Altun Kopri
            Road, replacement of existing pontoon bridges, and,
            technical support. Work projects will therefore be subject
            to an environmental screening, based on an environmental
            analysis which includes an evaluation of alternatives,
            including the "no-action alternative" and an
            examination of the direct and indirect effects of proposed
            actions, and, an environmental and social management plan
            will provide a framework for mitigation, monitoring and
            institutional strengthening actions to be integrated into
            the design and implementation of the project. Public
            consultation will be undertaken and environmental studies
            disclosed to the public. It is specified cultural property,
            i.e., monuments, works of art, or sites of significance,
            defined as having archaeological, historical, architectural,
            or religious significance - will be avoided, and, should new
            finds occur the authorities should be notified, and steps
            taken to preserve archaeological sites. Mitigation measures
            include appropriate engineering design, and, the project
            will assess feasible alternative/temporary options on a
            case-by-case basis, to comply with the local ecology.
            Wastewater must not enter streams without settling ponds,
            filters, or other processes. Co-ordination with
            stakeholders, and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) must
            begin in the design phase itself. The natural landscape
            shall be preserved to the extent possible, through
            operations that prevent unnecessary destruction, or scarring
            of natural surroundings. The report also addresses potential
            resettlement, and compensation issues, including in
            particular, ethnic groups to ensure these groups
            participate, and benefit from the project implementation.
            Grievance mechanisms will be in place to ensure compliance
            with these safeguards.
